Summary

The stl. file was prepared by three immunology students (Agathe, Aurélie and Marion) at the University of Toulouse (http://www.univ-tlse3.fr/) and allowed to print the CD80 molecule. This "Thing" was made within the frame of a pedagogical scenario aiming at introducing the students to the examination and handling of 3D structures and resulted in the making of a gallery of portraits of molecules with immunological interest. Printing was done at the CampusFab (https://fablab.univ-tlse3.fr/wiki/index.php/Accueil), the LabLab of the University (twitter account: @fablabups.)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Instructions

The 3D structure of the protein was recovered from the protein databank (http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/home/home.do) with the accession number 1DR9. It was downloaded using the .gz extension. Then, the structure was adapted for 3D printing using the Chimera software (http://www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimera/) and saved using the .stl extension.
It was printed on a MakerBot Replicator (http://www.makerbot.com/).

title: Bike Trainer Axle cap for solid axle bike.

description.text:
Have a bike you can't install a modern fork axle on?
I created these caps as so not to destroy the screw threads on my solid axle bike.
Currently testing, but they seem to hold up.

Printed at .3 with 100% infill using PLA. (might reprint in polycarb)

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eKW0aknpgSy

I bought a cool mini hotbed from F.Malpartida here: http://www.electrofunltd.com/ and at the time to install it I saw some glitches in my setup, so I had to design my own support. Now it works like a charm. This part complements my other thing here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1499950

This is a sturdy part, it has to be to minimize the platform's Z-wobble. Required print in ABS. at at least 30% infill. Maybe you have to use a longer M3 screw for the Z-level because of the height of the hot bed once it is mounted (depending on your setup). Hope this time I'm done with this project heheh.

title: How to make a Hobbed bolt

description.text:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4OEjcpbdBe0 2 pcs - 608 bearings
2 pcs - 626 bearings
1 pcs - tap screw M6 myhb - first with 0.7 groove depth
myhb1 - second with 0.9 groove depth
myhb2 - third with 1.2 groove depth

comments.text: What type of m6 tap should be used?
comments.author: Todd500

comments.text: Very cool Will print today.. :) Hope it works.. :)
comments.author: supernielsen

comments.text: Good job bro, thanks !
comments.author: Ataliva

comments.text: Ok, stupid question, do you run the same bolt through all 3 of the boxes, or is it one box to get the size indicated on each box?
comments.author: markdash

comments.text: One bolt need run through all 3 of the boxes. After last bolt be good.
comments.author: markdash

comments.text: Simple and very usefull. Thank you for your work
comments.author: AliAkdurak

comments.text: Mine did not work because tap have too much play against the bearing.
comments.author: DanMoto

comments.text: Need tap with 6 mm diameter like this http://www.amazon.com/Amico-1-0mm-Taper-Metric-Pitch/dp/B009PMINKS/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1392266629&sr=8-1&keywords=tap+m6http://www.amazon.com/Amico-1-...

comments.text: That one have a shank diameter of 5.3mm.  Mine is the same and it have too much play.  I probably need one with shank diameter of 6mm to fit the bearing exactly.

comments.author: Ybm

Development of Moineau pump: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7958 This is still under development, but the final goal is to develop this into a paste dispenser operated by a stepper motor and used in a 3D printer to form things from any paste-like material. For now, this operates with just a hand crank. Compared to the original, the rotation is reversed and the idea is to feed it from the top and have it push the pumped material out from the nozzle at the bottom. Printed and tested (by hand) a very rough, smaller prototype. Some pumping action was seen with water-flour mixture, so it works on a basic level. Printed and tested a spider coupling for driving the pump. Seems promising, the orbit of the rotor didn't seem to be any kind of a problem.

Print and try at your own risk. NOTE! The currently attached SCAD file only forms the hand-cranked version.
Bolt the nozzle to the bottom of the chassis. Insert rotor-crank assembly and turn clockwise.
Motor mount and couplings will be published when get them finished.

comments.text:
Hi.
I'm thinking on printing this for clay extrusion.
I've used professional cavity pump so far, and want to focus on the open-source design.
comments.author: eranglr

comments.text: The pump mechanism is non-pulsed by design, so that's not a problem. The problem with a printed pump is that it doesn't seal well enough to be able to pull the pumped material in, so it needs some sort of a transfer pump to feed it (unless the material can flow under it's own weight)
comments.author: eranglr

comments.text: As noted in emmett's original, one can probably drive it with a planetary gearbox with the drven pump part connected to the planet. The planet should have halve the teeth of the ring (and no sun gear).
comments.author: Proton

comments.text: That would be one option, but then you would have to put the gearbox either inside the suction side of the pump, which could be problematic, or outside, and then have to figure out sealing for a shaft that not just rotates but also orbits around.
comments.author: Proton

A RPi mounting for UM2. It includes a ball-jointed and adjustable mounting for the Raspberry Camera.
It doesn't come in the way of any component or axis, but still gives a nice camera view at the building plate when using it in combination with OctoPrint.
The RPi-mounting is designed for accomodating the RPi casing designed by 0110-M-P (files can be found under: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:922740).

Credits:
RPi Mounting inspired by Nigel Johnson's https://www.youmagine.com/designs/raspi-b-camera-mount
RPi Camera enclosure by frank26080115 (https://www.youmagine.com/designs/raspberry-pi-snap-together-camera-case)

A 3D printed Robot for Bioloid AX-12.

USB2AX interface. The USB2AX is a small ( very small device) interface to control Dynamixel servos like the AX-12 from a computer. It plugs into a USB port and has a 3-pin Dynamixel connector to be connected to the servos.

A typical use scenario is in a small mobile robot with a laptop or an embedded computer (like a Raspberry PI) as a brain and servos to move legs, arms or claws.

Basic Python software control on a RaspBerry Pi. Program based on Pypot software. https://poppy-project.github.io/pypot/

With Nanoroby you don't need any Bioloid robot brackets (sorry only two in the ankle). You only need to print the plastic elements that's fix perfect with AX-12 servos.

To print Nano Robi you need around 20-24 hours of printed time.

Same of the things you need to mirror in a 3D design program.

Please, I think is better to print only one piece and try to put the servo AX-12 inside the brackets piece before print everythink. Take one sandpaper and work with the plastic piece ultil both elements fix correctly. Then, when you know how its works you could print everything. It would be very easy but first you have to test.

You have to test how the system ( brackets<->AX-12) works withought screws-nuts.

This system is incredible easy and simple, and let you change for example one leg/ head or body element in minuts.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5B-6nG3HkAM

The boots have two elements that in my case I printed separate and I have to glue, but If you have a powerfull 3D printer you can joint (union boolean ) in a 3D program desing and printed in one simple piece.

I tested the printed elements of the robot and I think it have their correct thickness. My robot have more than 3 years old. It was my first expirience in 3D printed robots humanoids and it is durable. I printed with PLA.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3K_iI_kTAeE

More pictures at;
https://goo.gl/photos/Wvqcs5AgVxpczf4m8

Any problem please write on comment.

description.text:
This is a simple, fast and efficient Morse key. All you need is:
1) print the file named Key_Morse_v2_arm.stl
2) print two copies of the file named Key_Morse_v2_support.stl
3) finally print the file Key_Morse_v2_base.stl.

The file named Key_Morse_v2_full_view should not be printed and only serves to demonstrate the assembly.

To complete the Key you need several Screws, nuts and washers:

5 x M3 x 10 mm screw
1 x M3 x 15 mm screw

2 x 3 mm diameter washer (used to solder contacts)
4 x M3 nut

1 x 15 mm spring.
4 x M3 x 12 mm wood screw ( used to fix two support to the base )

title: Solidoodle Jigsaw Replacement Extruder mk3 and mk5 Mashup (Original by Lawsy)

description.text: This design is a mashup of the Mk3 extruder's body along with the Mk5 extruder's clip system.  It does not allow a quick hot end change at the expense of having the hotend secured firmly.
See lawsy's mk5 extruder replacement in the remix area of this page to find the instructions for replacing your extruder.  Thanks!

comments.text: Thanks!  I've never had problems with filament bending between the drive gear and hotend on my copy of the SD minimalist extruder until this last week and now it is happening all the time.  I tried temp adjustments and switching out the hotend.  I like lawsy's MK5 design, but I think the extra guide is going to win out for me.  I sat down with SketchUp yesterday to begin looking at the issue, but this is great.
comments.author: fredhag

comments.text: Is there a part missing from the files? looking at the picture there are three green parts but only two model files available.
comments.author: gckirk

comments.text: Yes, I left out the top filament guide piece because I did not modify it in any way.  I wanted people to be able to choose between the mk3 or mk5 filament guides so that they know this should work with both.  I can include the mk5 filament guide part in this thing, though, to make sure that it includes everything you need.  Thanks!
comments.author: gckirk

The stl. file was prepared by three immunology students (Sherazade, Aurore and Mickael) at the University of Toulouse (http://www.univ-tlse3.fr/) and allowed to print the CCL21 chemokine molecule. This "Thing" was made within the frame of a pedagogical scenario aiming at introducing the students to the examination and handling of 3D structures and resulted in the making of a gallery of portraits of molecules with immunological interest. Printing was done at the CampusFab (https://fablab.univ-tlse3.fr/wiki/index.php/Accueil), the LabLab of the University (twitter account: @campusfab.)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Instructions

The 3D structure of the protein was recovered from the protein databank (http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/home/home.do) with the accession number 2L4N. It was downloaded using the .gz extension. Then, the structure was adapted for 3D printing using the Chimera software (http://www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimera/) and saved using the .stl extension.
It was printed on a MakerBot Replicator (http://www.makerbot.com/).

In english below :
Mon entreprise a un distributeur de bonbon sur pieds mais ils ont perdu la clé pour l'ouvrir et le remplir de bonbons
J'ai proposé de percer la serrure et de la remplacer par un bouchon à visser.
J'ai utilisé une tige filetée et un écrou que j'ai percé avec une dremel et sa colonne de percage, puis j'ai créé un bouton pour faire tourner l'écrou et j'ai fini par un cache-écrou collé à la colle chaude sur la tige filetée.

My company has a big candy dispenser but they lost the key to open and fill it with candy.
I proposed to break the lock and replace it with a screw cap.
I used a threaded rod and a nut that I drilled with a dremel and his workstation, then I created a button to rotate the nut and I ended up with a nut covers stuck on the rod.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1VzCoDEjugn

Introducing the Wind Dragon and its valiant crew of gnomish wizards! I had so much fun deigning my Gnomedozer that I felt I needed to go bigger... (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:150113) This is a fairly epic print, and you'll need glue to assemble it, but I kept the pieces to a minimum. For best results, print both sets of wings and glue them together to get the framework on both sides. Thanks again to MakerBot for their Gnome scan which inspired these vehicle designs (I love making gnome variants, but they needed a playset). http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137617 I'll post a separate thing for the crew with individual models and split versions. All of these guys are scaled to standard heroic-scale gaming (28mm) and the ship is scaled to accommodate their 20mm bases. Enjoy!
Printed this guy in components at a .1 layer height, assembled them with superglue, and painted with acrylic model paints.

title: Raspberry Pi 2/3 case for Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a modified Raspberry Pi case intended to be mounted above the Prusa i3 control board. There are two pieces. One of them has screw holes that match the holes in the metal main structure of the Prusa i3. You can place your Raspberry Pi 2/3 in this case and mount it to your Prusa.

Instructions - use 4 x #4 1/4" wood screws to attach the two cases together. I couldn't find screws to mount the pi inside of the case, and it turns out it wasn't necessary. The pi sits firmly inside the case on its own. Use 2 x M3x10 screws to attach the whole thing to the metal super structure of the Prusa i3. Be sure to adjust the distance of the mounting holes to fit your Prusa's mounting holes. I may have measured wrong by a mm or two and had to adjust with a hand drill (rather than re-print the case).

Also - using Slic3r works well to prepare for printing but Simpli3D seems to have a better support structure algorithm and makes cleaning up the object after printing much easier. It's expensive at $149 but, for me, well worth it.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

2mm layers

Infill:

20%

description.text:
Made this for a friend of mine who wanted to put her old fitbit on her dog for some reason.
I found that rotating the part 30 or 45 degrees about the x axis and printing with support allows it to have good strength in the important directions. If you were to print it in a simpler way I'm not sure how strong it would be. I also scaled down the cap slightly in my slicer software, but my printer has some issues and probably wont be necessary for most people.

author: froggyarts

description.text:
Sort of an update of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86512.
This time I didn't use 123D but data from CT. Much more detail of course. Another deer this time.

Edit: I've tried twice now to print it and while the antlers are great the snout/nose/huge thing on the front will not really print well: too many details, too small a print.
So I'll do some experimenting with reducing faces and smoothing things up a bit. I'll be back ... Okay. I've now resampled data to a quarter of the faces (now being 62k). Also, I've tried another one of MeshLab's smoothing filters and it gave me the wanted result: Printing the smoothed version does work now, even if I make the model smaller, no more loss of any noses. The filter does one thing though: the proportions seem to have changed slightly. The skull and the antlers look like the guy was on steroids during his lifetime ;)
Anyway: have a look at the new data version:
Capreolus^Reloaded_62k_fractal_smoothing.stl
The last two picture show the prints. With the small one, one of the antlers doesn't print correctly anymore.
And that's my last word on capreolus, may he rest in peace...

description.text:
A convenient way to secure a piece of poster board to a 16mm rod (IE mic stand)!

The grip is super tight, you might need to manually open the jaws a bit to slide it in. I was not actually able to pull it out without opening the jaws, however.

Perfect for backdrops hung on microphone stands :)

description.text:
Case for your Raspberry Pi Zero. This case requires no hardware and snap fits shut. The HDMI and USB are accessible with case on. Two different top covers available, one with access to the GPIO pins and can have a pHat attached, or one with teeth.

I am also including the Autodesk Fusion 360 Files so you can change the designs on the top and bottom case if you want.
http://a360.co/22ZLPZB - Face case with teeth
http://a360.co/22ZLYMy - Face case with GPIO access
http://a360.co/21eHW3u - Case with no designs for customization

The Pi Zero used in the design came from here - https://grabcad.com/library/raspberry-pi-zero-2

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Supports:

No

200 Micron

zero

I printed this one with a 0.4mm nozzle with layer width of 0.4mm

title: HTC Vive Mixed Reality Camera Mount

description.text:
This is a camera mount for a HTC Vive controller. With this you can track your camera in your game space and film Mixed Reality videos. You'll need a 1/4" bolt, two washers and two nuts. I wouldn't tighten it up too much because I don't know how strong the Vive controller is. Just get it tight enough so that your camera is snug and doesn't move around. You use one nut to tighten the two parts together and the second to tighten against the camera.

The part with the flange goes on the bottom. Make sure the indentation on the top part is facing up to give you enough room to put the nuts on.

Here is a good example of a mixed reality video, with some instructions on how to set up the software. Here is a good discussion thread that goes into further detail.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.28mm

Infill:

10%

Is there any way I can order this mount printed in black/dark color and delivered to Sweden? I need something like this to mount my Sony pj820 camcorder on the Vive controller for Mixed Reality capture.
Please email me if someone can print and send a good copy of this mount, I pay for everything of course by paypal or similar.
Thanks in advance
Best Regards

description.text:
I added a glass bed to my CTC Bizer. This is what I made to hold the glass in place.

This solution does not pertrude above the buildplate and does not hinder the extruder.

It uses the four screws that holds the aluminium plate to keep the plastic locks in place. There is an oval hole to be able to adjust the lockation of the lock in relation to the aluminium plate.

The holes that allow the screws to contact the glass plate are 3.75 mm from the ledge. So the aluminium can't be thicker than that, otherwise the adjusting screws will not work.

Hardware:
8 M3 screws (I jused 8mm long)
8 M3 nuts

Printer:

CTC Bizer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

I set the automatic support in Simplify3D to a resolution of 2 mm. It then added the supports needed automatically.

title: E3D V6 Mount with Fan for CTC / Flashforge / Replicator - 40*40*20mm Fan Compatible

description.text:
I really liked MacNite's E3D mount for the Replicators and it works great as is, but I didn't want to use 10mm deep fans since my 20mm ones are SOOOO much quieter. So, I remixed it to allow 20mm fans.

Also, I added a center channel for the hot end wiring to feed up through. I think it looks cleaner, but that's my opinion. :-)

Suggestion: Pick up some Sunon HA40201V4-000U-999 fans over at Digikey. They're so quiet I can't tell they're even on, but they move a ton of air. They are 12V fans, so I just wired them both up in series.

title: 3Dator Bowden Extruder- With Replicator/FlashForge/CTC Dual Extruder Bracket

description.text:
The 3Dator Bowden extruder is great, but I wanted it mounted on my Replicator clone without drilling any more holes. Plus I made a few changes that worked out better for me.

-The bracket will fit 2 extruders, and has channels for routing the stepper wiring without it being in the way.
-The adapters have been modified to use M3 screws.
-The bearing bore on the end of extruder base has been extended to allow the bearing to have full contact with the stepper shaft and the base.
-I've created retainer loops to help keep the wiring in place and free of the spools.

title: Broom Handle / Extension Rod Tip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Got an El-Cheapo broom that lasted me about 3 months before the business end fell off. Turns out the cheap injection-molded plastic threaded end failed. I was looking around on Thingiverse to see if someone already CADed out a replacement I could just print and hammer back into the broom stick. Sadly, I was unable to find such a thingi and decided to CAD my own.

If you are looking for one of these, like I was 3 hours ago, here it is! I printed it in PLA at 0.1 mm height and 25% infill to try to get something that would last. I think I have seen this same type of threading in push brooms, mops, paint roller extension rods and maybe even a few of those ceiling fan cleaners. If you need it, use it! If you make it or use it, share a photo and what you used it for.

Orientation Note: Print Threads Up! no raft no supports (like I usually try designing, because I am not patient enough for supports)

https://youtu.be/6QUlFpkT0jY

Update: Added "reinforced" version that can accommodate some M4 hardware (bolt/washer/nut) to help the plastic layers and make the part stronger. I am also going to try to use this same design to make an "expanding base" version, where you tighten the screw after it is in the broom handle so that it expands slight to ensure a tight fit.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

25+%

Notes:

Print Threads Up! I don't know why my STLs always seem to export upside down.

I printed mine in HB PLA at 185 deg @ 50mm/s with 0.1 mm height to try to get a solid part. It took about 2 hours to print. I may print another in PETG to ensure it doesnt break again if my PLA part fails.

Fix-It Procedure

  1. Remove the busted plastic from broom head and handle. (I used a Multi tool to cut the pieces out)

  2. Print part (if you haven't already)

  3. Optional if you are printing reinforced version:
    Put bolt through washer, slide bolt through part (threaded end first! this is important because we don't want the head of the bold effecting how the part screws into the broom head) insert nut into back end and tighten firmly with screwdriver or wrench.

  4. Seat the part in the broom handle and 'gently' stab the handle into the ground, newly printed piece pointed down. This was the way I was the easiest way for me to get the end into the handle without extra tools or killing my hands. You want to use the momentum of the handle to drive the piece into it.

  5. Screw in the new tip into the broom end.

FreeCAD and Helixes to the rescue!

I used FreeCAD and my micro calipers to measure the broom handle and what was left of the busted part. Because the threaded end broke inside the broom head, I was able to get accurate measurements for the threading and the fit is quite impressive (especially for the part fitting and working the first try!). Just a few cylinders a helix with a path sweet and some final fillets and it was all done.

comments.text: Just a suggestion:  If you find that the replacement breaks too easily, go back into you CAD program and add a hole centered through the length of the part, and put a bolt (machine screw) in with a nut on the end in the handle.  This should provide quite a bit more strength than the plastic alone.  (You can use any old machine screw with matching nut that's long enough.  To assure the nut doesn't come loose, add thread locking compound, or a second nut jambed onto the first, or whack the extra threads with a hammer.)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Hey @ArizonaClark, I added a "reinforced" version with photos. Is that what you were thinking?
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Yep, that is what I had in mind.  Unfortunately, when we 3D print stuff, it can come out a bit less strong than we would like, and this is a simple and inexpensive way to add more strength.  It's a situation where the exact size of the bolt isn't critical, so one can use whatever happens to be at hand.
comments.author: T3CHKOMMIE

comments.text: @ArizonaClark what are your thoughts on changing the orientation of the part to enhance tinsel strength? Printing the part on its side with supports instead of straight up and down? Have you had any success doing that sort of thing? I am going to experiment with some TPU and PETG to see how long these parts last in real world scenario.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text: Is tinsel strength how many elves can be supported by a piece of garland?
comments.author: T3CHKOMMIE

comments.text: No problem I think we've all been there at one point or another. I hope the part worked out for you and you didn't spend your break painting!
comments.author: awdemuth

comments.text: Go ahead and cut it in half - it will help the threads print better and increase the strength since the grain will be going perpendicular to the shear stresses. Additionally the broom handle and bristles will help hold it together although I still recommend some good glue to hold them together.
comments.author: T3CHKOMMIE

comments.text: Not a bad Idea! I think I will CAD up that bolt hole now.
comments.author: ArizonaClark

author: T3CHKOMMIE

description.text:
"I call her Vera." This is Jayne's signature weapon from the Firefly series. I partly modeled it based on GameProps' design, but with higher detail: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:690281.

Print one of each part unless they have a numbered suffix. "_2" means print two, and "_2M" means to print one normally and a second one mirrored. Use support or not as appropriate for your printer. You will need three segments of 0.5 inch PVC pie to act as skeleton.

Painting

Assemble sub-units, putty cracks, and sand. To each part apply a coat of glossy black primer. Metallic parts use a light coating of silver or copper metallic paint. For mixed-color parts, mask off the black areas and paint the exposed areas. Other metals can use shades of gray acrylic, and one or two parts need colored paint.

After painting parts the parts can be glued together for final assembly. It can take a wash of burnt umber to make it weathered.

Generally you'll need one of each part. The exceptions are part names that end in "_2" (print two of those) and "_2M" (print two, one as-is and the other mirrored). You will need three lengths of 1/2" PVC pipe -- one for the body overall, one for the magazine, and one for the scope. Rough-fit the parts and then cut to length. There's no detailed guide but much can be inferred from reference images, and many of the parts fit together like a puzzle.

comments.text:
Anyone design a stand or mount for this yet?
Would love some kind of wall mount for my office. :)

title: X-Axis Endstop Mount Left Side for CTC, Flashforge and similar

description.text:
This is a x-axis endstop mount for the left side of a CTC, Flashforge or similar 3d printers.
During some problems with some sd-cards and the sd-card slot, I often got the problem that the printer runs into the walls. It was bad that there are no endstops on the left side for the x-axis and on the front side for the y-axis. So here it is a prototype of an endstop mount.

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height, 3 top/bottom surfaces and 2-3 perimeters

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

It is very possible that the 3 hooks won't fit on your printer because of the different tolerances. So this is also the first prototyp and it fits well for my printer. If I have more time I will design a holder which fits on all different CTC, Flashforge and similar printers.

comments.text: Exactly the standart limit switch is on the right side for the x.axis and it is x-max. This one is for the left side and it will be x-min. Normaly you won't need any minimum limits but in some error cases it can be helpful. I had a sd-card-slot problem and the printer hit several times the walls for minutes... So i desided to install a x-min and y-min endstop.

author: averypierce

title: Mounting bracket for the stock Ultimaker PSU

description.text: Note: This is thing is not maintained on here any more, further development/support it will happen on its Youmagine page.

I wanted to mount the PSU of my Ultimaker underneath it to get it out of the way. This is the bracket I designed for that.
I included the source file (OpenSCAD) so you can easily adjust the dimensions in case you want to use the design with some other PSU (or whatever else).
It's also available on Github.

Print out two brackets (I used something like 1.2mm wall strength, 20% infill).
Find a cozy place beneath your Ultimaker where the PSU will fit (towards the front worked great for me), fit it in, put the brackets on each end, mark the screw slots, drill four holes and put some of the M3 bolts from your Ultimaker kit through to secure the brackets and you're done.

comments.text: Won't it get too hot and melt the plastic or heat up the electronics that are mounted nearby?
comments.author: Nicolinux

comments.text: I checked the PSU before printing the bracket on a longish print and couldn't detect any significant heat built-up, which is why I dared to do this. Haven't yet experienced any issues, however the solution will only be temporary since I've already acquired a industrial 24V 360W PSU I intend the use for powering everything in the future.
comments.author: Nicolinux

description.text:
::EDIT3:: Check out my new website where you can vote for the next city to be built and 3D printed.
http://www.3Dprintedskylines.com

::EDIT2:: Now on Etsy!
https://www.etsy.com/listing/452049060/3d-printed-city-of-dallas-skyline?ref=shop_home_feat_1

::EDIT:: I've added Reunion tower (the ball) and the hyatt to the model and uploaded the new file here as well. Cheers!

This is a to scale model that I put together of a portion downtown Dallas. It is a very accurate replica of the area that it covers. The boundaries are set by the roads, Main St, N. Lamar St, Corbin St turing into Flora St, & Leonard turning into N Pearl and then S Pearl.

The scale is set at 1:6080, or every 1mm is equivalent to 20ft in real life. The tallest building in Dallas is the Bank of America Plaza which is 921ft; it is 46mm in this model.

More images on Imgur: http://imgur.com/a/btnxn
Enjoy!

comments.text: First I decided how large I wanted the whole print to be and then I calculated the scale by looking at google maps to estimate the size of the area I was looking at. The scale I came up with was 1:6000, or 1mm = 20ft. Then I built every building individually and imported them into the master file as components. You can find the height of most buildings by searching them online. I used that number to calculate the remaining dimensions of the building. I took a screenshot of the aerial view of downtown and overlaid it onto my base for the city in the model to correctly place the buildings.

description.text:
The new MakerGear M2 Rev. E version machines no longer require the use of a special wrench to deal with the Z-Stop bolt, so I've modified the tool holder to give folks the option of storing their Cricut spatula (or some other large tool) in the slot where the wrench was.

All else is the same....it still has a slot for your tweezers, a calipers, the screwdriver and the five hex wrenches.

comments.text: It's perfect, thanks :)
comments.author: Sazzefraz

title: Prusa I3 Bowden Drive Frame Mount

description.text:
Needed a way to mount my Bowden drive to my prusa I3 with a 6.5mm aluminum frame. Thought long and hard about where to put the excellent compact mount Schlotzz designed and this is what I came up with.

Designed for this compact bowden extruder drive mount by Schlotzz http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275593

You will need 2 M3 X 8 or 10mm screws to attach the bowden drive to the mount
You will need 2 M3 X 12 or longer to have sufficient length on the back of your frame to use M3 nuts and washers.
You will also need some zip ties to tie up your stepper motor cabling along the top of the frame (I did this to reduce possible interference from running it next to the power supply which is right below this mount on my version of the I3)

My printer is an Original Prusa I3 by Joseph Prusa, I'm not sure if it will accommodate other designs but it might be a good place to start for your printer! It puts the motor and filament feed far enough away from my frame that it will provide a good setup.

Printed at 1.2mm perimeters, 20% infill in PLA using Cura to slice. Turned out just how I wanted it to!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

ORIGINAL Prusa I3 - Joseph Prusa

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

author: Graptharshammer

title: Alarm Clock w/ Support for Many Alarms

description.text:
This is the hardware for an alarm clock that supports many alarms.  The design is not yet tested, and the firmware has not been written.  This schematic was made using Eagle 5.6.0 with the Sparkfun eagle library.  ENC1 is a Grayhill 61C11 rotary encoder, pins 4 and 5 provide quadrature outputs while 2 and 3 are either side of a momentary switch.  Timekeeping is handled by a DS1307 RTC chip.  Alarm is indicated via buzzer and flashing Luxeon LED.  I expect there to be errors, if you find any, let me know.  I'm still making the BOM and working on PCB artwork.  Most specced components in this design are surface mount.
NOTE: I've just put up a new version of the schematic.  I moved around the resistors and LED a little to make the schematic clearer.
-VE3HOP

Work in Progress.... This is for a DIY magnetic mixer from easy to find parts. It has mounting on the bottom for a 12v pwm fan speed controller, about 7 dollars on amazon or ebay, and a toggle switch. Uses a 12v 40mm fan with a permanent magnet from a old laptop harddrive glued to the blade hub. The lid has pegs to align the fan to the center and has posts on the side to use a rubber band to secure the fan.(no screws to vibrate off).

A little toy that I realized for my loved cat, Nina.
It’s a simplified but larger version of similar mazes that you can find in the commerce.

Credits also to Sebastian_v650, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1376759

The idea is to drop some croquettes in the middle of the plate and let the cat to find the best solution to grab them. My Nina had some difficulties at the beginning, but after a couple of days, she becomes smarter and found several shortcuts to get the prize!
I added a little video with Nina in action! (https://youtu.be/K9ANOgDozwQ).
In any case is a good system to feed slowly your cats and making them work to get what they want.

The 4 plates assembled measure 28,3 by 26,4 cm (11,1 by 10,4 inches) and you will need 90 sticks.

Printer:

Ordbot

Supports:

No

Notes:

I made this in PLA, printed with a 0.5 mm nozzle and 0.4mm layer thickness, no supports needed. The filling was set at (only) 10% for the plates and 25% for the sticks.
I recommend at least 3 borders and 4 top layers.
NB: for speed reasons, I suggest to print the sticks in horizontal position

title: Side Force Generator (SFG) for RC Plane Wing

description.text:
Side-force-generator (SFG) for approx. 35"~37" RC plane. SFGs can dramatically improve yaw authority and keep the aircraft "locked-in" during aerobatic maneuvers, especially in knife-edge orientation.

-The plane it was designed for and installed on is a TechOne 35" Extra 330 EPP (see photos, and can be found here http://goo.gl/mxSstX). Can be scaled for larger/smaller models.

-Spacer printing is optional but you will need some sort of spacer between the wing & SFG, approx. a few millimeters thick is plenty.

INSTRUCTIONS:
Reference my diagram to get an idea of how this is applied. The spacer goes between the wing tip and the SFG. The spacer should start at the leading edge of the wing and stop just before the hinge line of the aileron. The SFG should be lined-up with the spacer at the leading edge, but extends all the way to the trailing edge of the aileron. The spacer allows the aileron to move freely without any possible interference from making contact with the aileron.

author: KellenR

description.text:
Bracket for mounting and Arduino Mega 2560 + RAMPS 1.4 combination to a 2020 frame.

This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17228. The hole positions in the original were not quite right for my Arduino Mega 2560 board, so I adjusted them. Other people have reported this, but the pictures of the original thing clearly show it working, so I wonder if there are variants of the RAMPS board. My dimensions appear to be the same as this (http://www.hwkitchen.com/products/arduino-mega-2560/) or very close to it. I also extended the holes through the whole depth of the board.

The photos show it attached to the back left upright of an Eclips3D, attached with 3 M3 bolts.

description.text:
A simple one piece motor mount for 12mm OD Booms. Added relief for SHCS's to mount motor. Anti-rotation hole for M3 scew.

Update 4/28/2016: Motor Mount Rev4 - anti-rotation hole changed to 3.1mm in model to remove slop, should fit an M3 screw now. Added jig for drilling boom.

Update 6/4/2016: Be careful not to over-tighten the anti-rotation screw nut. It will crack the motor mount, which will lead to failure during flight. I found this out myself while doing a hard climb out.

title: RS-01 Ayrton Senna’s 1993 McLaren MP4/8 Formula 1 RC Car

description.text:
A tribute to Ayrton Senna, 22 years since he died May 1st, 1994.

By Brett Turnage
www.bti3dlabs.com
@3dprintRaceTech

Simplify3d
https://www.simplify3d.com/3d-printed-tribute-to-formula-one-icon-ayrton-senna/

3ders.com
http://www.3ders.org/articles/20160502-3d-printed-formula-one-rc-car-pays-homage-to-racing-legend-ayrton-senna.html

3dprint.com
https://3dprint.com/132295/formula-one-ayrton-senna/

Instructables write-up
http://www.instructables.com/id/RS-01-Ayrton-Sennas-1993-McLaren-MP48-Formula-1-3D/

Aggressively Driving for SENNA! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=opCakqTYoYw&feature=em-upload_owner

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PeReIkpCH18

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wVZLxG9ayZk

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LN48yEU7cEs

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4yQnyLyVDHA

​​​

This car honors arguably the greatest Formula One driver ever, three-time world champion Ayrton Senna, and his iconic 1993 McLaren MP-4/8 which he drove under both the McLaren/Marlboro red and white livery. If you have never heard of Ayrton Senna I highly recommend watching the documentary Senna (also check out the movie Amy by the same director)–it’s an amazing story of an amazing man who inspired the nation of Brazil and the world with his amazing driving. You can also watch this quick clip that Top Gear did a few years ago about Senna.​

https://vimeo.com/89217406

I always loved this car. This is the first unique car to emerge from the RS-01 chassis family and the first to be released… Being that it’s Senna’s car, I’m sure it will be outstanding in the rain, and do unworldly pole qualifying laps. :)

RS-01 chassis information can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1420189

This new car is an evolution of the RS-01 chassis with a highly detailed body that is very accurate to the original car, updated RS-01 suspension parts, u rims, and tires that can all be 3D printed. The chassis uses the running gear (carbon fiber rear shaft, differential, front uprights, motor mounts, carbon reinforced links) from a Tamiya F104-ver. 2 Pro F1 RC race car—parts that are readily available, and can use either foam tires, 3D printed tires, or rubber tires on either 3D printed rims or with the original F104 plastic rims.

I loved making this car; I hope that you enjoy printing and building it just as much.

-Brett Turnage

[email protected]

comments.author: wildcardfox

comments.text: No. The OpenRC chassis are different in many respects. I think the best way to look at these cars as a chassis family with one version being the OpenRC and a separate version being the Senna car. Some differences are: the body of the OpenRC car has very little room so it's a struggle when you start wiring things up, or you have to be very diligent and plan your wiring correctly. Things like the entire chassis plate, length of the chassis bottom, longer rear lower control arms, rear chassis pod, and other parts diffuser, etc, rims are all different—either longer or because I have more room in the body, are allowed to be designed to work better. This car, the Senna car was built for my chassis, so it is not shoehorning a serious racing chassis into a body that was not designed with it in mind. The only parts that are the same are the front suspension (which was improved in this version, and then shared with the OpenRC version), and how the rear suspension is setup. I have brought some of the cool features like rims and tires for the F109 which were designed for the Senna car over to the the OpenRC version, but this is my complete car whereas the openRC version was meant to compliment the OpenRC F1.

Description:

This is intended to be a gasket between the fan and heat sink on the qu-bd extruder.  I have broken 3 fans in the removal/reattach process.  I believe the bolts are putting too much stress on the plastic fan against the heat sink fins.  
In an attempt to spread this force I cut my first gasket from a scrap print and it has been working great. No more cracked fans since.  This is intended to be a replacement for that first gasket.  I added a shroud to limit the air flow to the upper part of the heat sink.  (I'll see if this increases noise, I don't expect any performance change...)  
The _v2 increased the bolt holes from 3mm to  4mm.

description.text:
I have a lot of designs that don't actually make to to here despite being interesting. I thought I'd share this one!

This one is currently building halfway up on my custom modded rostock in full size.
Don't be put off by it being a solid, Solids actually give much better surfaces than pre shelled objects as you can set single perimeter, vase mode, no fill and a few bottom layers. This gives the smoothest and most accurate skin.

I have a custom openscad script that I wrote and tweak for the overall tube skin shape with some sine waves worked in to the height and angle. The bird tiling effect is converted to a psuedo grey scale and then to a height map. The height map is then repeated around and up the modulated cylinder. After an Openscad render, the resulting STL is huge because of all the intricate height map detailing so I run it through meshcape to simplify the skin. This also has a slight smoothing effect, a bit like a skin forming as paint dries, like surface tension. I save the resulting mescape file and load it into slic3r with vase settings(1 perimeter, 3 base layers, no fill, vase mode) To make the container a bit more robust, I set a fatter nozzle size in the printer extruder settings so that the plastic squidges out sideways as well as just down.

print_settings.Notes:: I'd use at least 20% infill, or you'll have a problem catching the troughs of the waves with some form of support.

description.text:
It is a apparel making machine. Many years ago, before the industrial revolution, we made apparel by our hands, such as clothes, shoes and socks, all of these are made by our hands. People need to measure their height and angle before making the clothes. However, after industrial revolution, people began to use apparel machine and model to make apparel. Even a majority of people can wear the same angle apparel, but it did not mean the apparel which they wear is comfortable enough. Sometimes, you like a pair of shoes so much, but you found out that some angle is strange, even the size is correct. It is not so much strange, because everyone have different angle of their body. Thus, I designed this machine for making different angle apparel for customers.

I do not know how many years later people can really invent it, but I know not at this time. I believe people can invent the soft and creative material for 3D printing, and invent a kind of machine like I design above to make their apparel. So that all the apparel designer needs to do is just design the different kinds and style apparel. They do not need to consider about the angle and size any more, because the intelligent 3D printing machine can help the customers to do that.

As you can see, in the pictures, here are many different "legs" in the apparel making machine. All the "legs" in the machine can move to different angles. In the front, there have two intelligent computer to help people to measure their unique angle and put in into the machine to make apparel. Sometimes, customers want to make a creative angle, so I make two buttons on these two computers, and people can use it to control that two "legs" in the outside to customise their unique apparel.
My straw kept popping out of my soda so I added a hook onto someone's 8 bit skull. It's not very good but serves the purpose.

title: Logo Door
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
((This is not a daily earring ;-) I know they can be made and shared, but what about the usage of the name?))
My fiancÃ©e has a building block kit with one door missing. To avoid having a lego burglar breaking into the house, I printed it (3D printing is beyond awesome).
The dimensions are slightly off (A little more narrow to ensure it opens, mixed up the distance to the top a little, but other then that, it is a very similar & compatible door).
Picture of house with door following soon...

Printed on it's back with support (pp3dp UP: 0.25/normal, 40Â°/10mm^2 support), worked fine. Print the door facing sidewards for higher resolution details (currently printing another one).
The only downside on printing it on it's back with medium support settings is that the pin on top gets a little deformed but still worked. Printed standing on the wide side, axis upwards: Smooth teture, knob a little fragile, easy to clean (except the inner axis needed a bit of work with the knife, but printing with a improvised build platform atm). See new pictures (where only the white door is shown). I did not change the dimensions of the hole and pin (both 5mm diameter), so depending on the printer's setting and smudge it may require you to slightly sand it or put a coat of nail polish on etc. (or simply change the 3D model). Worked fine here, especially since it is held between lego blocks anyway. Without support, printing this laying or standing sideways on the axis might work best, but would require some clean up afterwards.

DrawingBot es una versión Open Hardware de la famosa maquina AxiDraw la cual es un sencillo y moderno plotter, capaz de escribir o dibujar sobre casi cualquier superficie plana. Se puede escribir con plumas, marcadores permanentes, y otros instrumentos de escritura para manejar una variedad sin fin de aplicaciones. Sus características de diseño únicas un cabeza de escritura que se extiende más allá de la máquina, por lo que es posible dibujar en objetos más grandes que la propia máquina.

DRAWINGBOT is an Open Hardware version of the famous machine AxiDraw which it is a pen plotter, capable of writing or drawing on almost any flat surface. It can write with fountain pens, permanent markers, and other writing implements to handle an endless variety of applications. Its unique design features a writing head that extends beyond the machine, making it possible to draw on objects bigger than the machine itself.

comments.text: Hi friend. I think the hole on Z_carrier and  Z_Soporte is a little bit small for 3.5mm rod. And the wall of Z_carrier is easy to break during installing the rod.
comments.author: zaitianzhiya

comments.text: I agree the holes on the Z_Soporte are a fraction too small.  I need to drill out with a 3.5mm dremel that caused the sides to break very easily.  Others have noted too.  My solution was to 1. Use TinkerCAD to add a little box on each side of the hole boxes to make them thicker and add another flatten box as a roof over the new walls and the original.  This rendered a very robust support that I could drill out just a smidge, you don't want any play in the head, but you do want it to drop freely.  The holes of the Z_Carrier, I found to be perfect, you can push a rod though and it holds firm as it should.  In the final model the rods are held snug in the carrier and the pen floats up and down freely without any X or Y play (freedom). Also, I had to print without supports as they were clogging up the hole and could not be removed. One done it is a very satisfying design and the pen holder snapping a sharpie in and out, is great!

comments.text: The four pieces, similar to washers that help guide the belt around the four bearings, are not available as a separate file. They are only shown in the plate.

comments.text: Just assembled mine, this peg is to hit the limit switch which is installed on the motor mount below where the belt goes as shown by the small black rectangle in the blue rendering (also seen as a silver rectangle in the red renders just above the threaded rod). Hope that helps. As far as the 'washers', I'm not sure what you mean. I just put a screw through each bearing with a (non-printed) washer to allow the bearing to turn.
comments.author: Menneset

comments.text: OK, thanks. I installed my limit switches on top of the feet/motor mounts where the bottom flat side of the switch is in the same plane as the bottom / face of the stepper. It engages the upper plate of the carriage quite nicely.
comments.author: Smashley

comments.text: Interesting, I hadn't bothered to look at the full plate stl. These would probably be good to have as the bearings do have a bit of play in them as the screws I'm using aren't snugly fitting in the centre. Regarding the limit switches I've seen more do it as you have with them on top, and was about to do that myself when I looked at the renderings more closely. It probably doesn't matter either way, as long as the contacts on the switch aren't shorting against the motor.

title: Da Vinci 1.0 stepper driver fan mount

description.text: This is a fan mount for the Da Vinci 1.0's stepper drivers, it uses a 60mm fan, and an existing screw mount, and screw on the printer's board.

comments.text: Interesting i had overlooked the stepper drivers on the DA Vinci.
comments.author: technomastermind

comments.text: Hi, I'm also using an mk8 extruder, although bowden, which added friction to the filament, and caused missed steps on the extruder motor, therefore I bought new A4988 stepper drivers with current adjusting pots, and had to create custom PCB boards to mount them since regular a4988s don't align with the boards pins. All the axis' drivers stay cool except for the extruder stepper since I cranked up the current, I even put a copper heat sink on it. I'm currently waiting for a nema 23 stepper motor that I ordered to replace the nema 17 extruder motor, for more torque which will in return require more current, so I designed this fan for when that comes in mainly.
comments.author: technomastermind

This project is a tracked robot chassis to carry a ZEB1 Lidar scanner (see http://www.beckengineering.com.au/?page_id=2441). The rover comprises a lighter weight but heavier duty chassis, motors, motor mounts, drive wheel and suspension for the tracks and swing arms off the Dagu T'Rex and a mounting arm, including oscillating mount for the ZEB1.

You can see a movie of it with ZEB1 mounted, scanning a house here:

https://youtu.be/p9bI1B1qdbc

Videos of it without the oscillating mount here:

https://youtu.be/_8VQwqkNp9o

The replacement chassis accommodates upgraded motors. The drive sprocket and gear boxes are replaced and helper springs increase the cargo capacity. The sprocket has also been re-sized to properly engage with the tracks and is sized to fit a popular and available 12V metal gear motor. The design allows small adjustments to the alignment of the motors to achieve better tracking.

Using a 5000mAh LiPo battery, it will run for 30mins to 45mins.

This is the additional hardware:

02 x MEC-30148 : 131:1 Metal Gearmotor 37D x 57L mm (12V)
02 x MEC-30182 : Pololu Universal Aluminum Mounting Hub for 6mm Shaft M3 Holes
Aluminium RHS - See rhino file for details. I include a drilling tenmplate to facilitate attachment of the T'Rex suspension components to the RHS.
assorted screws, nuts, washers
4x100mm RC Car springs

You will also need the drilling guide and suspension spacer from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:996812
These are used to attach the helper springs to the swing arms.
This original project was supposed to be a sufficient upgrade to allow the DaguT'Rex to carry more load, but the motors/gearboxes weren't sufficient, hence this more comprehensive re-build

remixed_from.author: effedebe
remixed_from.title: autolevel Z ROBO 3D: remixe for short 5/16"-18 (not Coupling )

description.text:
Hey
This is a remake/design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:687502 because the dimensions were not correct for me. I've also made some improvements as well.
With this you can use the original nuts.

Take a look at this guy for more details for this setup: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:349935

This is a work in progress as I still need to wire up the switches.
There is a left and right as well as a versions with a built in support.

Some design notes: 'measurement' ; 'part spec'
Carrage hollow nut ~12.7mm ; Nut set to 12.3mm
Carrage hollow nut depth 7.5mm ; Nut depth set to 7mm
z nut 12.45mm ; Nut hole set to 12.7mm
z rod 7.75mm ; Hole set to 8.6mm
Clamping hole ; 3.6 mm diam 3mm bolt
Clamping nut ; 6.1 mm edge-edge 3mm nut
MicroSwitch holes ; 1.8mm #2 wood screw

Noticed switches activate at different heights above the bracket. May need to move holes or bend lever to compensate.

Hope this helps.
Design files included

Update(5/17/2016):

No longer WIP (it seems to work just fine). Also new pic.
After wiring it up and printing a few parts, I discovered I developed a significant z banding effect. Looking at a newer Robo3d R1+ model I found they did indeed remove the lever on the microswitch. This shortens the switch travel distance reducing the difference of the trigger distances between the two sides. After removing the lever on the microswitch the zbanding went away. I'm guessing it was caused by overcompensation or incorrect compensation from differing switch trigger height on both sides.

Also this is part of my slic3r start gcode relating to autolevel:

; Slicer start G-Code
G21 ;metric values
G90 ;absolute positioning
M82 ;set extruder to absolute mode
M107 ;start with the fan off
M190 S[first_layer_bed_temperature] ; wait for bed temperature to be reached
M104 S[first_layer_temperature] ; start heating extruder 1
T0 ; set the active extruder to 0
G28 X0 Y0 Z0 ; home all axes
G1 Z5 F8000 ; lift nozzle off the bed
M109 S[first_layer_temperature] ; set the extruder temp and wait
G28 X0 Y0 Z0 ; Home Z again in case there was filament on nozzle
M565 Z-0.85 ; set Z probe offset
G29 ; probe the bed
G0 Z3 ; Lift nozzle before lateral movement
G0 X110 Y120 ; Center nozzle on print area
; End of Slicer start G-Code

There's some extra movements that's to my own preference but basically:

G28 ; home
M565 Z-0.85 ; set Z probe offset,
G29 ; probe the bed

Robo 3D

author: marsrecall

print_settings.Notes:: This part has been designed to work with a variety of delta printers.  The holes are hexagonal, which helps to make them more accurate (due to less slump when bridging the top layers).  No support material is required, and you shouldn't need a brim.

remixed_from.author: ZiggyRobo
remixed_from.title: Robo 3d Auto Bed Leveling (Auto Bed Height Compensation)

description.text:
Most deltas have some amount of effector tilt as the head moves around the print surface, so a Z sensor that is offset from the nozzle will introduce errors due to tilt.

This sensor has zero X and Y offset, which means that effector tilt doesn't affect the measured Z value.

It automatically deploys and retracts, and seems to work very well.

Specification
Deployment Automatic
Bed surface Compatible with all bed surfaces
Bed preparation None
Sensing method Physical touch probe, which triggers an optical sensor
X offset from nozzle 0
Y offset from nozzle 0
Repeatability Around 0.01mm
Printer type Recommended for Delta printers

Here is a video showing how it works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U1EvF51eAaQ

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Kossel Mini / Kossel XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This part has been designed to work with a variety of delta printers. The holes are hexagonal, which helps to make them more accurate (due to less slump when bridging the top layers). No support material is required, and you shouldn't need a brim.

All the parts you'll need. Left to right, these are: 2 x M3 20mm, 1 x M3 6mm, 2 x M3 nuts, 2 x small 'wood' screws, 1 x M2.5 30mm, 1 x cut down terminal block, 1 x optical endstop, 1 x bicycle spoke, 70mm steel piano wire, 1 x printed sensor holder, 1 x 9 gram servo. Partially assembled with the servo, and endstop screwed to the printed part. This part is bent using pliers, and if you have one, a set of Z bend pliers. If you don't have those pliers then normal pliers will work OK. Test fit the parts together and ensure that the bicycle spoke is free to fall under its own weight. You want the holes to be loose enough that the spoke falls freely, but tight enough so that there's no wobble. The holes should need very little (if any) cleanup. Every printer is different, so your measurements will probably be different to these. The critical point here is that the end of the spoke is flat, and it is just below the sensor line when the spoke is deployed. Also, when retracted, the bubble on the end must be well above the end of the nozzle. Finally, the assembly is screwed into the effector plate, between two arms.

A few of the prototypes.

I started with the Robo 3d Auto Bed Leveling file, and moved things around until it fit on a delta. Then it seemed logical to see if I could get this to work with an offset probe, and get it to swing out of the way when retracting.

Firmware configuration

You need to tell your firmware that it is using a servo, as well as a Z min endstop.
Both the servo and optical endstop need a 5V supply.

Details for Marlin / Ramps are below.

Hardware setup with RAMPS

To get the hardware working on a RAMPS 1.4 board, you need to:

1) Jumper the 5V rail to provide power to the servos
2) Connect the servo to the set of pins closest to the reset button. The brown wire goes to the edge of the board.

3) Connect the optical endstop to the Z Min pin on the RAMPS board. Note that this needs all 3 pins connected.

Optical endstop connections. Red is 5V, Black is ground, White is signal.

Marlin firmware setup

Download the very latest RCBugfix from here:
https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/tree/RCBugFix

Make the following changes in configuration.h

#define min_software_endstops false // If true, axis won't move to coordinates less than HOME_POS.
  #define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // KosselPro actual: -22.919
  #define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0  // KosselPro actual: -6.304
  #define Z_RAISE_BEFORE_PROBING 50  // How much the Z axis will be raised before traveling to the first probing point.
  #define Z_RAISE_BETWEEN_PROBINGS 7  // How much the Z axis will be raised when traveling from between next probing points.
  #define Z_RAISE_AFTER_PROBING 15    // How much the Z axis will be raised after the last probing point.

  #define Z_PROBE_END_SCRIPT "G1 F7000 X0 Y0 Z50" // These commands will be executed in the end of G29 routine.
  // #define Z_PROBE_ALLEN_KEY
#define NUM_SERVOS 3 // Servo index starts with 0 for M280 command
#define Z_ENDSTOP_SERVO_NR 0
#define SERVO_ENDSTOP_ANGLES {{0,0}, {0,0}, {5,80}} // X,Y,Z Axis Extend and Retract angles

Note: some servos work backwards to this. If your servo deploys instead of retracts, then you need to replace the endstop angles with this: {{0,0}, {0,0}, {80,5}}. You can also tune the angle of the servo arm by playing with the numbers.

I also recommend turning EEPROM on:

#define EEPROM_SETTINGS

Setting up your slicer

You need to set this code as your start G code section in the slicer.

M106 S0; // Set fan speed to 0
G28;
M280 P0 S5; // Deploy probe.  Adjust angle to suit.
G1 F7000 X0 Y0 Z100;  // Move to 100mm above the bed 
G29;  // Auto level
G1 X0 Y0 Z20 F5000;  // Move to 20mm above the bed

Deployment and retraction

It helps if you make some custom buttons in Pronterface to deploy and retract the probe. These are:

M280 P0 S5;  // Deploy
M280 P0 S80; // Retract
G30; // Probe single point
G29; // Probe entire bed
Setting Z height

Firstly, level your bed by doing the paper test. Then do a single point probe at the middle of your bed (G30). The Z height reported in Pronterface will be the Z offset you need to use.

The command to set the Z offset is:

M851 Z-10.0

Don't forget to save this to EEPROM with M500.

Most probes will end up with the Z height offset being about 10mm. Adjust as necessary.

Adjusting to get good adhesion

You can adjust the Z offset to change how squished the first layer is. More negative numbers mean more squish. Less negative numbers mean less squish.

You can even adjust this via the control panel.

comments.text: would this work on Cartesian as well as delta printers?
comments.author: jordomaller

comments.text: Yes, but there’s no point in doing so.  The problem with deltas is effector tilt, which doesn’t happen on cartesians - and the whole point of this sensor is to be immune to effector tilt.

comments.text: Hi great job . I am bulding a rostock printer amd decide to use Your probe to autolvl .However I stock with the firmware config , in new malin 1.1.0-RC7 i am unable to find some options from description , can may You post the line nombers where to find the options from descriptio ( I can not find there define Z_RAISE_BEFORE_PROBING 50  // How much the Z axis will be raised before traveling to the first probing point.and many others , I am blin or just dump ;p
comments.author: Mahtrox

comments.text:
It seems that you're neither blind nor dumb, it's just that Marlin RC7 removed those options :-) They are now:
Z_PROBE_DEPLOY_HEIGHT
Z_PROBE_TRAVEL_HEIGHT
The devs have also changed the bad curved movements between probe points, so these defaults should work fine. Let me know how you get on.

title: 2016 Ghostbusters Reboot Pack 6 digit display box GB16

description.text:
This is the display box for the 6 digit (seven segment) display. And it is a work in progress, but not sure when I will get back to it. It looks nice (when sanded) and accurately makes the small gap between the two pieces.
The pieces just fit together but nothing is really there to hold them together. I will probably end up gluing them together but it will make it a real pain to work on or change the display board.

I have made a set of three display boards for the three digital displays and they are all Arduino controlled with just two pins and a support library to make the updating of the displays easy. There are mounting holes and alignment pins to hold the display board.

https://youtu.be/fTLgRZiHqSY

print_settings.Notes:: If you find the ring doesn't fit you (I am a big guy, so it may be too big) you can edit the files on tinkercad.com to meet your needs.

description.text: Wanted a cool NFC ring, so what better choice than dickbutt!

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

Build this face down ring up and it will use minimal supports. The supports it does use mostly all pull off at once. To get the NFC tag in the ring you will need to be able to pause the build and drop it into the provided gap. You can tweak this yourself over at tinkercad.com. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7nKo7GQehO9-dickbutt-nfc-ring

When I printed this I paused the print at layer 33 and put the NFC tag in at that time. Make sure to check your gcode viewer to determine when yours will be at the correct height to place the NFC tag.

If you find the ring doesn't fit you (I am a big guy, so it may be too big) you can edit the files on tinkercad.com to meet your needs.

Tinkercad files

https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7nKo7GQehO9-dickbutt-nfc-ring

title: HICTop 3dp-11 X Axis Belt Holder - Reinforced

description.text: X-Axis belt holder to replace the original which warped under tension. This one in reinforced to prevent warping in the front to back direction. It may also prevent warping in the up and down direction, time will tell.
Had to ream the bolts holes to fit the screws. Otherwise it worked well. This is a great companion to the X Right End that I designed a few weeks ago. The one with the printed Z screw nut.

comments.text: completely stock 3dp11 bearing and it doesn't fit over them at all. to narrow by 1mm compared to stock...stock one is 31mm wide yours is 29.99997mm wide
comments.author: Thumper72

comments.text: I do not doubt you. However, I have been using this for over a year without a problem. The only issues I had were trimming and chasing the screw holes to proper size. I have broken 2 belt tensioner arms from this design -- https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1368354 -- with the belt holder remaining firm. The tensioner arm, I solved this issue by printing the arms with 4mm wall thickness. This made a much stronger piece. Using PLA.
comments.author: Thumper72

comments.text: Nice idea, do you know what size the original allen bolts are including length? I just ordered this type of carriage and will use your belt holder, its not here yet so just want to order them now. Thanks for the share.
comments.author: Gaz23

comments.text: 3mmX8mm I believe. The carriage main plate has an integrated threaded collar that this screws into.

Aww I see thanks. The holes in your holder are 2mm wider than stock.
http://i1171.photobucket.com/albums/r557/garyskynet/IMG_1311_zpsl8aotmbp.jpg

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this in eSun PET-G to keep warping to a minimum, and it came out very well. You may need to drill out the mounting holes a bit to match your Screw-of-Choice (tm).

description.text:
I bought this nixie tube kit from eBay a while back:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Nixie-Tube-clock-KIT-with-IN-12-LED-Alarm-Black-/172173151885

It's a really great kit, but the power section of the kit can pack a helluva punch if you accidentally pick it up the wrong way. But, at the same time, the kit has an attractive component layout, and I didn't want to cover that up. So, I made this case to keep the buzzy bits away from prying hands---I'm looking at you, my fellow co-workers...

There are vents in the bottom of the model, so it should provide decent airflow with some rubber feet. I haven't noticed the clock warming up at all, so they might not be necessary. But, better safe that sorry.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this in eSun PET-G to keep warping to a minimum, and it came out very well. You may need to drill out the mounting holes a bit to match your Screw-of-Choice (tm).
